**Preface to *Zhouyi Cantong Qi with Chapter Divisions and True Meaning***

The Preface states: According to the *Biographies of Divine Transcendents*, the Perfected One Wei Boyang was a native of Shangyu in Kuaiji. His family had long worn the hairpin of office, yet he alone did not serve, cultivating the True in seclusion and nurturing his aspiration in emptiness and non-being. Profound in literary expression and versed in all apocrypha and prognostications, he embraced simplicity and guarded his purity, following only the Dao. He regarded carriages and robes as mere husks and chaff.

It is unknown from which master he received transmission, but he obtained the *Ancient Text of the Dragon and Tiger Classic* and fully grasped its wondrous purport. Thereupon, he drew upon the *Zhouyi* to compose the *Cantong Qi* in three scrolls.

Moreover, it is said that as the subtlest details remained unexhausted, he composed the *Supplement to Omissions and Elisions*, a single scroll further expounding the profound mysteries of the alchemical canon. His exposition often employed allegory and borrowed events, veiling and revealing through variant texts. He secretly imparted this to Xu, the Attendant of Qingzhou, who then concealed his name to annotate it. By the reigns of Emperors Xiao and Huan of the Later Han, the Master transmitted it to his fellow townsman Chunyu Shutong, whereupon it circulated in the world.

The *Cantong Qi* was composed because the Master held that the cultivation of the elixir shares the same path as the creative transformations of Heaven and Earth, and thus he relied upon the images of the *Zhouyi* to expound it. Without exception, he borrowed the relationship of ruler and minister to illustrate inner and outer, employed *li* and *kan* to directly indicate mercury and lead, arrayed *qian* and *kun* to establish the measure of the crucible, clarified them as father and mother to bind the beginning and end, united them as husband and wife to constrain their intercourse—likening them to male and female—manifested them in generation, analyzed them into yin and yang, guided them through inversion and reversion, and revealed them in the dark and new moons. He connected them with ascent and descent, matched them with the hexagrams and lines, embodied them in transformation, followed the handle of the Dipper to take its cyclical stars, divided them by dawn and dusk, and illuminated them through the clepsydra. Thus, *qian* and *kun* became the crucible, yin and yang the embankments, water and fire the mechanism of transformation, the Five Agents the aids, true lead the progenitor of the medicine, mysterious essence the foundation of the elixir, *kan* and *li* husband and wife, and Heaven and Earth father and mother. Mutually deploying the eight trigrams, driving and directing the four seasons, dividing the three hundred eighty-four lines to circulate the firing times, and revolving the five planets and twenty-eight constellations around the crucible—only then could the Water Tiger conceal its form, lodging in *geng* and *xin* to turn westward, and the Fire Dragon subdue its body, pursuing *jia* and *yi* to revolve eastward.

The *Zhouyi* states: "The sage, having perceived the traces of the world, models them in form and likeness, symbolizing their proper attributes." The Master thus took up these images. If not one of utmost penetration in the world, who could have achieved this? Behold: he cleaved open the primordial chaos, split asunder the vast expanse, directly pointed to the numinous root of Heaven and Earth as the progenitor of the medicine, and clearly beheld the sagely mother of yin and yang as the foundation of the elixir. He disclosed the origin of the One Qi’s transformations and revealed the basis of the Great Foundry’s generation. If not one of utmost comprehension in the world, who could have achieved this?

Some may fix the clepsydra, divide the sundial’s hours, cluster yin and yang, dispatch spirits and ghosts, compress the three thousand six hundred breaths of primordial qi, and revolve the seventy-two seasonal nodes. They may move the sixty-four hexagrams’ yin tally, with the Celestial Pass in hand, and drum the twenty-four solar terms’ yang fire, with the Earthly Axis at heart. Heaven and Earth cannot conceal the mechanism of creation, nor can yin and yang hide the root of nurturance. Thus, the spirit transforms the primordial square, and pure generation arises. If not one of utmost clarity in the world, who could have achieved this?

The *Cantong Qi* states: "The Golden Crucible of Chaos, white and black in accord; the Dragon Horse descends its essence, the mare and stallion intermingle their qi. Like frost upon horse’s teeth, like jade and dog’s fangs; mercury dwells with the astonished maiden, cinnabar mercury unites with the infant’s body." Distinguishing the qualities of the medicine, subtly revealing the elixir’s form, it fully encompasses the latent work of completed transformation and greatly manifests the portents of what has yet to germinate. If not one of utmost numinosity in the world, who could have achieved this?

Some borrow the images of the lines to embed these matters, yet dare not leak the celestial mechanism, nor can they bear to conceal the profound principle. Thus, they unfold without cease, repeatedly weaving and threading, unable to desist, and so form scrolls. Their aim is to point out the essential Dao, to draw in those to come, and to grieve for those embodied beings who, in the end, become mere ghosts of utter yin. If not one of utmost benevolence in the world, who could have achieved this?

There are those who penetrate the virtue of the Three Luminaries, roam the essence of the Eight Poles, ingest golden sand to transform their form and substance, and feed upon fiery mercury to refine their essence and spirit. Thus, they attain a body of pure yang, a spirit born in the true dwelling, shed the Three Corpses to transcend the Three Realms, and ascend to the Upper Clarity as Perfected Transcendents. If not one of utmost authenticity in the world, who could have achieved this?

As for those who divide the *True Cantong Qi* into chapters and meanings, they take borrowing as their fundamental principle, with no fixed standard above or below. The text is broad, yet the Dao is upright; the matters are manifest, yet the words are subtle. Later generations discuss it, each taking what they see: some divide the characters to debate, others combine the sentences to annotate. There is no lack of divergent streams and separate currents, giving rise to disputes over beauty and ugliness. Those of shallow learning seek to investigate it but find it difficult to attain immediate clarity. Since the discussions at the beginning and end differ, the right and wrong in their choices remain uncertain. Now, chapters and sentences are divided and fixed, valuing the coherence of principle. The meaning is upright, the text follows, and the "Gate of Medicines" is appended, thus organizing four scrolls into three volumes, comprising ninety chapters to correspond to the number of the Nine Yangs. It is titled *True Meaning of the Divided Chapters*.

The main text is written in red, while the ancillary meanings are in black, clearly visible for perusal. The upper volume contains forty chapters, the middle volume thirty-eight, and the lower volume twelve. Within it is the *Song of the Crucible*, whose words and principles are interlinked, and whose characters and phrases are fragmented, making division into chapters impossible. Thus, it is preserved alone to correspond to the number of the One Water, symbolizing the completion of the yin and yang numbers in the Dao of the elixir.

Furthermore, following the *True Cantong Qi*, I have composed the *Illuminating Mirror: Diagrams and Secrets*, a single scroll appended to the end of the lower volume, to further open the doors and windows of the *True Cantong Qi*. Having received transmission from my teacher and devoted years of study, I dare not conceal the profound text. Thus, I have diligently completed this true meaning, hoping—if only by a ten-thousandth part—to bequeath it to later generations.

Preface by Peng Xiao, the True One of Flying Crane Mountain, who embodies Unity.

**The *Zhouyi Cantong Qi: Divided Chapters with Penetrating the True Meaning*, Volume One**

*Annotated by Peng Xiao, the True One of Flying Crane Mountain, Gentleman for Court Audience, Acting External Minister of the Bureau of Sacrifices in the Ministry of Rites, and Bearer of the Purple Gold Fish Bag*

**Chapter One: Qian and Kun as the Gateways of the *Yi***

Qian and Kun are the gateways of the *Yi*, the parents of all hexagrams.
Kan and Li serve as the wheel’s rim and axle, guiding its true course.

Before the Great Change, the Great Void, and the Great Beginning, though the supremely subtle was already latent, no signs or sprouts had yet appeared.
At the juncture of the Great Commencement, the Great Simplicity, and the Great Ultimate, there arose the undifferentiated, which is the state of primordial chaos.
Within it lay the essence of the True One, the origin of heaven and earth, the mother of the myriad things.
Once the One qi took form, the Two Modes divided. Thereafter came Qian and Kun, yin and yang, the Three Powers, the Five Phases, and the myriad things with their countless names.
Thus, Qian and Kun are established as the warp of heaven and earth, and the operation of yin and yang becomes the key to creation. With Qian and Kun in place, yin and yang move within them.

Master Wei states that the refinement of the Golden Elixir of Return aligns with the path of creation. Borrowing the images of the *Yi* to expound it, he invariably begins by delving into the True One’s chaotic qi of heaven and earth as the root foundation. Next, he draws upon the essential purity of Qian and Kun and the traces of their revolving motion as the model, following the numerical patterns of *Kan*, *Li*, *Pi*, and *Tai* to establish the instruments of punishment and virtue, and seizing the mechanism of yin-yang transformation to complete winter and summer.
Yin arises after noon; yang emerges at midnight.
In movement, it rises from the yang nine; in stillness, it follows the yin six—this is the great purport of elixir refinement.
Thus, Qian and Kun serve as the crucible and vessel, Kan and Li as the enclosing frame, water and fire as husband and wife, yin and yang as dragon and tiger, the Five Phases as the weft containing true essence, and the Three Powers as the warp gathering pure vitality.
Cold comes and heat departs, circulating through the three hundred and eighty-four lines;
The hare rises and the crow sinks, ascending and descending over three hundred and eighty-four days.
All these begin with the substance of the two hexagrams, Qian and Kun, and unfold into transformation.
Hence it is said: Qian and Kun are the gateways of the *Yi*, the parents of all hexagrams.

**Chapter Two: The Four Hexagrams of the Female and Male***
The four hexagrams of the female and male serve as the lofty key.

The Way of yin and yang is enveloped and upheld, much like a skilled charioteer who follows the marking line, grasps the reins and bit, aligns the compass and square, and follows the wheel tracks. By abiding in the center to govern the exterior, the calculations are bound to the pitch pipes and calendrical cycles. The lunar phases consist of five or six days, with the warp and weft serving the sun’s command. Combined, they form sixty, with firmness and yielding possessing outer and inner aspects.

In refining the golden liquid and returning elixir, within the crucible lies the Golden Mother’s Flowery Pond—also called the Golden Womb Divine Chamber—where the four hexagrams Qian, Kun, Kan, and Li serve as the medicine. The "lofty key" refers to the pivotal mechanism, while "enveloping" means to encompass and enfold. Thus, there are the yin crucible and yang furnace, the firm fire and yielding tally, all adhering to the sixty-four hexagrams, cycling endlessly in mutual employment. Within this, the movements of spring, summer, autumn, and winter are enacted, dividing the twenty-four qi, segmenting the seventy-two seasonal nodes, compressing a year’s twelve months of climatic conditions into a single month, and further condensing a month’s conditions into the twelve hours of a day and night. The clepsydra is calibrated, the two crescents are distinguished, midnight and noon are separated, yin and yang are regulated, the dark and new moons are harmonized, the dragon and tiger are united, all in accordance with the great numbers of heaven and earth and the transformative mechanisms of yin and yang. If control and guidance are without error, and movement and transference are without loss, then externally, the tally of yin and yang is exchanged, and internally, the bodies of the dragon and tiger are generated. Thus it is said: A skilled craftsman follows the marking line without deviation; an able charioteer grasps the reins and bit without wavering, aligning with the compass and square and adhering to the wheel tracks. This is a metaphor for the adept refining the elixir in accordance with the fire phases.

The lunar phases of five or six days constitute thirty days; each day and night corresponds to one hexagram, totaling sixty hexagrams. The four hexagrams Qian, Kun, Kan, and Li are the parents of the medicine, the pivotal mechanism of the crucible and vessel. However, this does not refer to the numerical correspondence of day and night but rather encompasses the sixty-four hexagrams as a whole. "The warp and weft serve the sun’s command" means the hexagrams and lines serve as the warp of daily use, while the weft consists of the pitch pipes and calendrical calculations. "Firmness and yielding possess outer and inner aspects" refers to yang as firm and yin as yielding, with water and fire, metal and wood mutually serving as outer and inner.

**Chapter Three: The Hexagrams *Zhun* and *Meng* at Dawn and Dusk**
At dawn, *Zhun* governs the affairs; by dusk, *Meng* assumes the duty. Each day and night corresponds to one hexagram, employed in sequential order. In circulating the fire phases of yin and yang’s ascent and descent day and night, all adhere to the sequence of one hexagram governing each day and night, beginning with the two hexagrams *Zhun* and *Meng* as the starting point. *Zhun* governs at dusk, and *Meng* at dawn, establishing this as the order.

**Chapter Four: The Hexagrams *Ji* and *Wei* at Dusk and Dawn**
*Ji* and *Wei* extend to dusk and dawn, ending only to begin anew. The celestial stems and earthly branches serve as the measure, with movement and stillness varying in earliness and lateness. *Ji* and *Wei* refer to the two hexagrams *Jiji* and *Weiji*. "Dusk and dawn" signify the alternation of dark and new moons, yin and yang, brightness and obscurity, going and returning. "The celestial stems and earthly branches serve as the measure, with movement and stillness varying in earliness and lateness" means yang pertains to movement and yin to stillness. Within the twelve hours, the early and late phases are divided, with yin and yang ascending and descending, the fire phases cycling endlessly in mutual employment.

**Chapter Five: Spring and Summer Rely on the Inner Body**
In spring and summer, rely on the inner body, from *zi* to *chen* and *si*. In autumn and winter, employ the outer application, from *wu* to *xu* and *hai*. The yang fire advances the tally from *zi* to *si*, where pure yang governs, seeking outer yang from inner yin. The yin tally retreats the fire from *wu* to *hai*, where pure yin governs, with outer yang attaching to inner yin. This is the principle of the inner and outer bodies, the pattern of flourishing and decline, beginning with *Fu* and ending with *Kun*, all determined by the images of the lines.

**Chapter Six: Rewards and Punishments Correspond to Spring and Autumn**
Rewards and punishments correspond to spring and autumn, with dusk and dawn aligning with cold and heat. The line texts embody benevolence and righteousness, expressing joy and anger in accordance with the seasons. Thus, they correspond to the four seasons, and the Five Phases attain their principles. The generative qi of spring is called reward; the astringent qi of autumn is called punishment. From *zi*, *chou*, and *yin* is spring; from *mao*, *chen*, and *si* is summer—these are the four yang fire phases. From *wu*, *wei*, and *shen* is autumn; from *you*, *xu*, and *hai* is winter—these are the yin tally phases. Within the twelve hours, the fire tally is circulated in accordance with these four seasons and Five Phases, aligning with dusk and dawn, cold and heat, benevolence and righteousness, joy and anger. The images of the lines must not deviate by even a hair’s breadth, hence it is said to be without loss. Within the crucible, the four seasons remain unblemished; within the image, cold and heat are unified—thus the elixir is surely formed.

An ancient song says:
The sage seizes the intent of creation,
Grasping sun and moon to place within the crucible.
Subtly inverting the essence of heaven and earth,
Boring through yin and yang to move spirits and ghosts.
Who recognizes the sun’s soul and moon’s spirit?
Those who do are true immortals.
Refining and ingesting for a thousand days,
The body, devoid of yin, cannot die.

Therefore, in refining the golden liquid and returning elixir, if one does not model the images of heaven and earth’s creation and follow the natural principles, there will be no accomplishment.

**Chapter Seven: Heaven and Earth Establish Their Positions**
Heaven and earth establish their positions, and the *Yi* operates within them. Heaven and earth are the images of Qian and Kun. "Establishing positions" means arranging the positions of yin and yang in correspondence. The *Yi* refers to Kan and Li. Kan and Li are the two functions of Qian and Kun. The two functions have no fixed line positions, circulating through the six voids. Their coming and going are unfixed, their ascent and descent without constancy. Hidden and submerged, they transform within; encompassing and enveloping the myriad things, they serve as the warp and woof of the Dao.

"Heaven and earth establish their positions" means modeling the crucible and vessel after the image of *Jiji*. "The *Yi* operates within them" refers to the circulation of yin and yang, Kan and Li, and the fire tally within. Having modeled the crucible and vessel after Qian and Kun, one further installs the Golden Mother within to complete the Three Powers of heaven, earth, and humanity.

Kan and Li, the two functions without fixed line positions, refer to the external application of water and fire, their movement and stillness without constancy. Thus they circulate through the six voids, their coming and going, ascent and descent without fixed positions. Now hidden, now manifest; now active, now latent—they serve as the origin of all transformations and the mother of generation and completion. Hence they are called the warp and woof of the Dao.

**Chapter Eight: Using the Non-Existent to Govern the Existent**
Using the non-existent to govern the existent, the vessel’s function is emptiness. Thus in the ebb and flow, Kan and Li vanish. The non-existent is the dragon; the existent is the tiger. The non-existent is the yang qi of mercury; the existent is the yin essence of lead. Lead and mercury reside within the empty vessel yet cannot generate transformation on their own. Through the ascent and descent of Kan and Li, propelling the four seasons, generation and completion become manifest. This is using the empty vessel to govern the existent with the non-existent. As the *Ancient Text of the Dragon and Tiger Classic* states: "When the existent and non-existent mutually govern, the Vermilion Bird flames in the void." Thus when yin grows, yang retreats; when yang rises, yin recedes. In the alternation of ebb and flow, Kan and Li vanish in accordance with the seasons.

**Chapter Nine: No Careless Creation**
No careless creation in speech, no groundless emergence in discourse. Drawing on evidence to verify effects, measuring and aligning with the numinous. Extending categories to structure characters, tracing principles for proof. Kan is the lunar essence of *wu*; Li is the solar radiance of *ji*. Sun and moon form the *Yi*, their hardness and softness in balance. Earth reigns over the four seasons, weaving the beginning and end. Green, red, white, and black each occupy their quadrant, all receiving the power of the central palace, the achievement of *wu* and *ji*. The sage does not carelessly fabricate empty words to delude later generations. Thus he cites the sun and moon as evidence, measures and aligns with the numinous, distinguishes hardness and softness, points to metal and water, compares dragon and tiger to grasp their images, moves yin and yang to fathom their essence, completes the work with the five earths, and binds it with the four seasons. Thereupon green, red, white, and black cycle in succession, all receiving the power of *wu* and *ji*.

Kan as the lunar essence of *wu* is lunar yin; *wu* is yang. This is yin containing yang, resembling metal-tiger born within water. Li as the solar radiance of *ji* is solar yang; *ji* is yin. This is yang containing yin, resembling mercury-dragon born within fire. Thus in refining the elixir, one gathers the essence of sun and moon, harmonizes the numinous qi of yin and yang. When the cycle of stellar numbers is complete and the movement of yin and yang concludes, all credit returns to the virtue of earth, and the numinous essence is perfected. "Extending categories to structure characters" refers to the character *Yi* resembling sun and moon.

**Chapter Ten: The *Yi* as Image**
The *Yi* is image. Suspended images manifesting clarity—none greater than the sun and moon. Exhausting the numinous to know transformation: when yang departs, yin arrives. The spokes interlock as the wheel turns, emerging and entering, rolling and unrolling. The *Yi* contains three hundred eighty-four lines; drawing lines to extract tally-signs, the tally-signs refer to the sixty-four hexagrams. From the dark moon to the dawn of the new moon, Zhen arrives to receive the tally. At this moment, heaven and earth unite their essence, sun and moon mutually embrace. The male yang spreads its dark offering; the female yin transforms the yellow womb. Chaos intermingles, the root foundation is established. Cultivating and nourishing the bud, concentrating spirit to form the body. All things tread forth from it; no movement fails to arise from it.

The *Yi* is image. It is the sun and moon uniting to form one. The golden liquid returning elixir is nothing other than the union of the sun and moon’s yin and yang essences. Thus the essence of yin and yang emerges and enters, rolls and unrolls; day and night cycle endlessly, returning to the beginning. Approximately sixty-four hexagrams, following three hundred eighty-four lines; drawing lines to extract tally-signs, fire follows advance and retreat. When yin comes, yang departs; when yang hides, yin acts. The qi of east and west intermingle; the sentiments of husband and wife harmonize. At this moment, Zhen arrives to receive the tally. Heaven and earth unite their essence; sun and moon join their souls and spirits. Chaos resembles the hen’s egg, the two crescents uniting like chaos. The yang dragon and yin tiger within chaos bear the qi of mutual resonance, establishing the root foundation, nurturing the bud, until spirit congeals into form, ultimately becoming a refined entity. Thus within the crucible chamber is another heaven and earth. All creatures, from the smallest to the greatest, arise from it.

The male yang belongs to heaven, hence the dark; the female yin belongs to earth, hence the yellow. These are the old yang and old yin. Qian the father and Kun the mother alternately employ the fire tally to its utmost. Thus one knows that within a single crucible, the transformations are each illuminated as heaven and earth’s movement, giving rise to the ten thousand kinds. If the fire timing is lost, the addition and subtraction overdone, cold and heat unseasonal, advance and retreat misaligned—then within heaven and earth, by what seasonal markers would things generate their images? By what yin and yang would dragon and tiger be born?

**Chapter Eleven: At This, Confucius**
At this, Confucius praised the primal chaos, the virtue of Qian and Kun pervading the void. Investigating antiquity to the primordial sovereign, the *Guanju* established the beginning. The qi of marriage and capping intertwine; the first year then germinates. Confucius praised the Dao of the *Yi*, dividing Qian and Kun as the origin of the myriad things, establishing *Xian* and *Da* as the model for husband and wife. He split the primal chaos, chiseled the undifferentiated, revealed the forms of ghosts and spirits, and communicated the sentiments of heaven and earth. Thus ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife, male and female, the five phases mutually generating and overcoming—the mechanism of the myriad things’ transformations was exhausted. Thus Qian and Kun illuminated their pervading void.

Therefore Master Wei compared the *Yi* to establishing the crucible vessel, moving the celestial mechanism, uniting the forms of dragon and tiger, harmonizing the bodies of husband and wife. Initially, the complete non-existent form and essence resembled the primal chaos. After kindling the fire and moving the tally, the male and female essences intertwined. Thus the mutual longing of the *Guanju*, the seeking of marriage and capping. From the first kindling of fire, the first year’s germination is fitting. Sun abiding in moon, the dragon and tiger’s forms are established.

**Chapter Twelve: The Sage Is Not Born in Vain**

The sage is not born in vain,
Gazing upward to perceive the manifest celestial tally.
The celestial tally advances and retreats,
Expanding and contracting in accord with the seasons.
Thus the *Yi* governs the heart of Heaven.

The sage Fuxi, looking up and down,
Examined the patterns and numbers,
Discerned the nature of the myriad things,
And bequeathed them to later generations,
That those yet unenlightened might peer into the apertures of Heaven and Earth,
Plunder the essence of yin and yang,
Grasp the root of creation,
And distinguish the forms of tally and response.
Mutual generation and overcoming,
Advance and retreat, expansion and contraction—
All lie within the palm’s grasp.
Thus it is said: the *Yi* governs the heart of Heaven.

Therefore, he established the symbolic forms,
Probed the utmost essence,
Prepared the crucible and furnace,
Circulated the tally and fire,
Followed the water clock’s measure,
Practiced the hexagrams and lines,
Determined the hours,
Divided the seasonal nodes,
To exhaust the great reckoning of Heaven and Earth.

**Chapter Thirteen: The *Fu* Hexagram Establishes the First Sprout**

The *Fu* hexagram establishes the first sprout,
The eldest son inheriting the father’s body,
Founding the primal foundation upon the mother.
Ebb and flow respond to the pitch pipes,
After three days, clarity emerges,
*Zhen* receives *geng* from the west.
On the eighth day, *Dui* receives *ding*,
The first quarter hangs level as a plumb line.
On the fifteenth, the Qian body is complete,
Fully replete in *jia* and the eastern quarter.
The toad and hare, the moon’s spirit,
Gaze upon the hexagram’s nodes.
When the reckoning is done, they bend and descend.

The *Fu* hexagram, in establishing the first sprout,
Conceives the mother.
On the fifteenth day, the Qian son and the double brightness ascend and descend,
Relying upon the pivot of the Dipper.
*Zhen* receives *geng* from the west.
On the eighth day, *Dui*—
The qi of sun and moon shines doubly bright.

The hare spews forth radiant light.
In the seven-to-eight Dao, the eldest son inherits the father’s body,
Establishing the six yin lines below, with the first changing to one yang line—
Hence it is called "founding the first sprout."
This refers to the *Kun* hexagram’s lowest line transforming into a *Qian* line;
*Qian* is the father, and from the third day the moon takes form, the yang number reaching its half.
The Wei Duke lodges this hexagram’s inner structure, completing *Zhen*,
While *Kun* is *Zhen*’s root—thus it is said, "establishing the primal foundation."
*Zhen* is *Qian*’s eldest, and from here, following the seasons, it gradually transforms,
Until the fifteenth day, when it becomes pure—hence it is said, "inheriting the father’s body."
Likewise, by the eighth day, the first quarter is complete,
An analogy for the cauldron’s metal and water each at half.
Fullness emerges from the eastern quarter,
The toad and hare’s spirits an analogy for the cauldron’s metal and water,
Full and perfected by the fire’s timing.
The moon’s waxing is likened to this: within half a month’s three *hou*,
The yang fire advances, drawing and adding within the cauldron,
Over half a day’s six *chen*, receiving the fire tally,
Giving rise to these transformations and first sprouts.
"Seven-to-eight Dao complete" refers to the fifteenth day,
When the *Qian* body is fully realized.
"Bending, descending low" refers to what follows:
From the sixteenth day onward, the yang fire retreats, and the yin tally is employed.

**Sixteenth Turning Receives the Mandate, Chapter Fourteen**
The sixteenth turning receives the mandate,
*Xun* meets *xin* at dawn’s level brightness.

**Gen** aligns with south at *bing*,
The twenty-third day marks the waning half-moon.
*Kun* and *yi* on the thirtieth day—
In the northeast, its companion is lost.
When the cycle is exhausted, they yield to one another,
The succeeding body revives the dragon.

That "the sixteenth turning receives the mandate" means:
From the sixteenth day onward, the yang fire first retreats,
And the yin tally begins to arise.
That "*Xun* meets *xin* at dawn’s level brightness" is like
The initial advance of the yang fire,
As when the moon first appears on the third day.
That "the twenty-third day marks the waning half-moon" is again
Like the waxing half-moon in meaning:
Metal and water are each half.
That "*Kun* and *yi* on the thirtieth day—
In the northeast, its companion is lost" means:
The yin tally reaches this point,
And the yang fire is entirely consumed.

Within one month, yin and yang are each half,
Yin and yang yield to one another,
Water and fire depend on each other.
When one month ends, it begins anew,
Again employing the *Fu* hexagram to commence,
Thus it is said: "The succeeding body revives the dragon."

**Chapter Fifteen: Ren and Gui Pair with Jia and Yi**
*Ren* and *gui* pair with *jia* and *yi*,
*Qian* and *Kun* encompass beginning and end.
Seven and eight make fifteen,
Nine and six likewise correspond.
These four combine to thirty—
The yang qi seeks extinction and concealment.
The eight trigrams array the celestial bodies,
Their movements never stray from the center.

*Ren* and *gui* are yin;
*Jia* and *yi* are yang.
Yin and yang pair together,
Meaning the elixir mother within the *Qian-Kun* cauldron
Receives the qi of the yang dragon and yin tiger in union,
Thus it is said: "*Qian* and *Kun* encompass beginning and end."
Seven, eight, nine, and six—
These four combine to thirty days.
Within thirty days, seven and nine correspond to yang numbers,
Six and eight to yin numbers.
*Qian* and *Kun* each take half,
And by the thirtieth day, all is complete—
Yin tally and yang fire both conclude.
Thus, when firing the elixir for one month,
One follows the eight trigrams,
Arraying the celestial bodies in their courses,
Advancing and withdrawing, ascending and descending
Through north and south, east and west,
So that yin and yang unfold and coil,
And metal and water harmonize.
If the firing is mistimed,
Drought and flood disrupt the seasons;
The principles of generation and completion are impaired,
And the dragon and tiger’s forms are hard to retain.
Those who practice firing must ponder this carefully.

**Chapter Sixteen: The Primordial Essence is Subtle and Hard to Perceive**
The primordial essence is subtle and hard to perceive—
One infers and verifies it through signs.
When at rest, observe its image,
And model its form accordingly.
Erect a gnomon as a standard,
Divining auspices to determine fortune or misfortune.
Issue commands in accord with the seasons,
Never missing the moment when the lines shift.
Above, examine the patterns of the *River Chart*,
Below, sequence the earth’s flowing forms.
In the center, investigate the human heart,
Comparing and considering the Three Powers.
In movement, follow the hexagrams’ rhythms;
In stillness, rely on the *Image*’s words.
*Qian* and *Kun* are put into practice—
Only then are heaven and earth ordered.
How could one fail to be cautious?

**The Primordial Essence as the Divine Spirit Within the Crucible**
The primordial essence is the divine spirit and true essence within the crucible—
The primordial *qi* of heaven and earth.
Though it cannot be grasped or seen,
It subtly follows the mechanisms of transformation,
Giving birth to and nurturing the myriad things.
Since it is profound and obscure, difficult to perceive,
One must infer and verify it through signs,
Erect a gnomon as a standard,
And issue commands in accord with celestial omens.
Thus, gazing upward, one observes the patterns of heaven;
Looking downward, one examines the principles of earth.
Only then can one unite the *hun* and *po* of heaven and earth,
Harmonize the contraction and expansion of *yin* and *yang*,
Establish the Three Powers,
And determine the auspicious and the sovereign.
Following the hexagrams’ images and the lines’ words,
Distinguishing dawn and dusk,
Regulating ascent and descent,
One achieves the harmony of *Qian* and *Kun*,
The union of husband and wife,
The intercourse of dragon and tiger,
And the ordering of heaven and earth.

The above discusses adhering to the clepsydra’s marks,
Directing the talismanic fire,
Clarifying withdrawal and addition,
Distinguishing advance and retreat—
Never deviating from the celestial motions of sun, moon, and stars.
Thus, within the crucible, the divine essence of the myriad things
Is produced in accord with the four seasons.
How could the adept who directs the talismanic fire fail to be cautious?

**Chapter Seventeen: The First Principle of Governance**
The first principle of governance
Encompasses the subtle and the hidden,
Opening and unfolding to spread forth treasures.
It is the pivotal handle of the essential Dao,
The guiding thread of transformation.
When the lines and images stir within,
Fortune and misfortune arise without.
The five planets move in errant or orderly paths,
Responding to the seasons and stirring in resonance.
When the four and seven fall into discord,
They shift and stray, bowing and rising.

The first principle of governance
Is the sequential beginning of the adept who directs the talismanic fire.
Once the metal is smelted and the crucible formed,
One must secure and seal it, ensuring subtlety and concealment.
To "open and unfold, spreading forth treasures"
Means the inner metal flows freely, its fluids abundant,
Gold and water depending on one another.
Again, one follows the handle of the Dipper,
Traversing the twelve earthly branches,
Aligning the five planets within the four and seven.
The four and seven are the twenty-eight constellations.

If the celestial omens and portents fall into disarray, their signs and tokens failing to align, then fortune and misfortune arise from the moving lines, and the talismanic fire loses its rhythm with dawn and dusk. This causes the outer five planets to fall into chaos, and the inner five qi to lose harmony. When the four and seven fall into discord, the circumpolar stars scatter and stray, and the crucible fails to generate and complete its work.

Though the external fire moves and progresses, if the inner talisman remains still and unresponsive, then the celestial soul and terrestrial spirit fail to unite. Thus, the stars fall into disorder, the sun and moon deviate from their courses, the four seasons lose their balance, and the myriad things fail to flourish. This arises from the mismanagement of the fire, where summer and autumn lose their proper measure, causing the crucible to suffer from unseasonable drought or deluge.

**Section Seventeen of the *Compendium of Literary Governance* states:**
The Literary Governance Compendium summons the scrutiny of the Three Ducal Ministers.
All officials and functionaries oversee their respective domains.

The Literary Governance Compendium refers to the Dipper’s handle bearing the basket—six stars known as the Hall of Literature: the first is the Supreme General, the second the Secondary General, the third the Noble Minister, the fourth the Director of Destinies, the fifth the Director of Records, and the sixth the Director of Calamities. The Three Ducal Ministers are the six stars beneath the Dipper’s handle, paired two by two, called the Three Terraces. Those who govern the world assist the Son of Heaven above in harmonizing yin and yang and aligning the four seasons, while below they ensure the suitability of the myriad things, enabling ministers and grandees to fulfill their duties. This mirrors the crucible receiving the qi of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things, generating and transforming within.

When yin and yang fall into discord and the four seasons lose their proper measure, it is like the adept who directs the talismanic fire, whose regulation and balance exceed or fall short—hence the admonition and reproof.

The elixir of golden fluid and returning cinnabar lies hidden in the two words: *lead* and *fire*. To complete the work from beginning to end, one must first obtain true lead, and then—even more difficult—true fire. How could this be lightly discussed? Thus, Master Wei expounded it broadly, fearing that later generations might yet fall into confusion.

**Section Nineteen: The Sun Harmonizes the Essence of the Five Phases**
The sun harmonizes the essence of the five phases,
The moon receives the discipline of the six pitch-pipes.
Five and six make thirty degrees,
Once the cycle is complete, it begins anew.
Tracing origins and seeking ends,
The threads of survival and decay.
At times the ruler grows arrogant and excessive,
Overbearing and transgressing the Dao.
At times the minister is devious and obsequious,
His conduct straying from the proper path.
The waxing and waning of crescents and full moons,
Discord and change bring misfortune and blame.
Those who enforce the law admonish and criticize,
Their clumsy outcries leaving faults for the ruler to bear.

The sun harmonizing the essence of the five phases means that each month it once conjoins with the moon. The moon receiving the discipline of the six pitch-pipes refers to the metal and water within the crucible, which each month receive half of the pitch-pipe qi. There are six pitch-pipes and six complementary pipes, which the sun and moon share between them. The sun, moon, five planets, and celestial weave together generate the myriad things, just as the crucible receives the external qi of yin and yang, the talismanic rise and fall of midnight and noon, the essence of the five planets’ progression, and the purest union of sun and moon. Adversity and prosperity follow one another, survival and decay intertwine, cycling anew—beginning with *Return* and ending with *Receptive*.

Within the divine chamber, the yin essence resides in the central palace, dwelling in the virtue of earth and symbolizing the ruler. If the crucible responds internally but fails to act externally with focus, it is because the sovereign has grown arrogant and excessive, causing tribute from the four directions to cease. When ministers are devious and obsequious, the timing of the fire falls into error, the waxing and waning of crescents and full moons become irregular, and the dark and new moons bring misfortune and blame—all of which are laid at the ruler’s feet. The ruler is the metal essence, the earth virtue, the divine chamber. The ministers are the five phases, the six pitch-pipes, the essence and qi. Success or failure rests with the adept who directs the talismanic fire. From this, the maidservant flees, the red dragon bolts, the divine essence departs—what then remains of the golden fluid to seek?

**Section Twenty: The Celestial Pole Receives the Proper Measure**
The celestial pole receives the proper measure,
At ease and unhurried, it governs below.

The Hall of Light enacts governance, yet the state’s origin harms the Dao.
Within, it nurtures the self—tranquil, empty, and primal.
Tracing back to the hidden and luminous, it inwardly illumines the body’s form.
Seal the mouth, fortify the numinous root.
The Three Lights sink into obscurity, warming and nourishing the child-pearl.
Though unseen to the eye, it is near and easily sought.

That the celestial pole receives the proper measure,
At ease and unhurried, governing below—
This speaks of the divine embryo dwelling in the central chamber,
A metaphor for the ruler abiding in the Hall of Light, like the North Star.
The qi of yin and yang and the five phases are the ministers.
When ruler and ministers govern within,
Like the North Star fixed at heaven’s center,
Then the qi of yin and yang and the five phases harmonize in accord,
The fluids of metal and water in the crucible-chamber flourish,
And the ruler may nurture the self,
Abiding in tranquility, effortlessly empty and primal,
Undergoing transformation naturally.

“Tracing back to the hidden and luminous, inwardly illumining the body’s form”:
This means that metal can conceal brightness yet also illuminate itself,
Gaining fire to amplify its radiance.
“Seal the mouth”:
The *dui* is the mouth.
Once the golden tiger’s numinous root is settled in the central chamber,
One must secure and seal the crucible’s opening,
Directing the true essence of the Three Lights inward
To nurse and nourish the child-pearl and numinous mercury—
Hence, “the Three Lights sink into obscurity.”
The Three Lights are the yang fire, yin tally, and golden embryo,
Symbolizing the sun, moon, and stars.
Externally, there are also Three Lights,
Distributed within the moving and still lines and time-marks,
Within the yin and yang tally-fires,
Transforming and taking form.
For within and without, each possesses the body of yin-yang transformation—
This cannot be exhaustively discussed.
At this subtle and wondrous stage,
Without oral transmission, it is difficult to convey in writing.

When the golden mercury is in the crucible,
Its transformations are unfathomable, beyond perception.
Yet if one employs the celestial mechanism to regulate it,
Using the pivot of the cosmic pattern,
Then the golden mercury dares not flee,
And dragon and tiger may unite in mating—
Hence, “it is near and easily sought.”
The *Yin Fu Jing* says:
“The cosmos is in your hands,
The myriad transformations arise in your body.”

**Section Twenty-One: The Yellow Center Gradually Permeates Order**
The yellow center gradually permeates order,
Moistening and suffusing the skin.
First rectify, then refine to the end;
The trunk stands firm, yet the branch may not be grasped.
The One veils and conceals it—
The world knows it not.
The *Book of Changes* says:
“The noble one, yellow at the center, permeates order,
Abides in proper position, embodies integrity—
Excellence resides within,
Flowing through the four limbs,
Manifesting in deeds—
This is the height of beauty.”
This speaks of the golden tiger in the crucible,
First receiving the external qi of yin and yang,
Gradually moistening and suffusing the skin.
Once it first receives qi, the initial sprout arises,
The branches and trunk are rectified,
And in the end, the fruit is borne.
It is a metaphor for the true mercury of golden cinnabar first sprouting buds.
The One is water.
For the water’s root is true metal within the vessel,
Securely sealed and concealed—
Ordinary people cannot know it.

**Section Twenty-Two: Supreme Virtue Acts Not**
Supreme virtue acts not,
Nor seeks through scrutiny.

Lesser virtue acts,
Its function unceasing.
When the upper aperture closes, it is called "being";
When the lower aperture closes, it is called "non-being."
Non-being serves to uphold the above,
Where the divine virtue resides.
This is the method of the two apertures,
Where the golden qi mutually requires.

The supreme virtue is water above;
The lesser virtue is fire below.
Water and fire conjoin—
This is called Qian and Kun.
Water above remains ever still,
Abiding in yin without acting,
Nor seeking through scrutiny.
Fire below moves ceaselessly,
Circulating through the twelve celestial stems,
Its function unending.

The upper closure is called "being"—inner water.
The lower closure is called "non-being"—outer fire.
Non-being serves to uphold the above,
For fire circulates the qi of the four seasons and five phases,
Nourishing and upholding the divine embryo.
Thus it is said, "Above, the divine virtue resides"—
The divine embryo of golden mercury.
As for "the method of the two apertures, where the golden qi mutually requires,"
It speaks of the two qi of water and fire, yin and yang,
Mutually sealed and requiring one another to form the divine medicine—
All else is but a deviant path.

Master Wei was enlightened by this chapter,
Profoundly clarifying the great principles of the method and the归旨 of the divine medicine.

**Chapter Twenty-Three: Knowing the White, Guarding the Black**
Know the white, guard the black,
And the numinous brightness will come of itself.
The white is the essence of metal;
The black is the foundation of water.
Water is the pivot of the Dao,
Its number named "One."
The beginning of yin and yang,
Mysteriously containing the yellow sprout.
The master of the five metals,
The river chariot of the north.
Thus lead appears black without,
Yet harbors golden splendor within.
Clad in coarse robes while holding jade,
Outwardly a madman.

The white is metal;
The black is water.

Knowing the root and function of metal and water as the foundation of the medicine,
The divine essence will naturally arise within the vessel—
Thus it is said the numinous brightness comes of itself.
White metal is born from water,
And so becomes the divine vessel.
The body of water is inexhaustible,
For the dual natures of metal and water form the pivot of the Dao.
Water’s number is One,
The origin of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, the five phases, and the myriad things.
Water is One, fire Two, wood Three, metal Four, earth Five.
"Mysteriously containing the yellow sprout" refers to metal and water generating the yellow sprout.
The master of the five metals is the river chariot of the north.
The river chariot is water and fire,
For the qi of water and fire circulate to generate the five phases.
Thus lead appears black without yet harbors golden splendor within:
Before lead is transformed into white metal,
It lies concealed within the ore,
Outwardly black while inwardly holding golden radiance—
Like the madman clad in coarse robes while holding jade.

**Chapter Twenty-Four: Metal as the Mother of Water**
Metal is the mother of water,
The mother conceals the child in her womb.
Water is the child of metal,
The child shelters in the mother’s womb.
The perfected one is most subtle,
Now present, now absent.
Like a great abyss with flowing locks,
Now sinking, now rising.
Retreating, they disperse,
Each guarding their own domain.
Water is born from metal,
Metal is the mother of water—
This means metal generates water,
Yet in turn conceals its form within water,
Thus hiding the child in the womb.
"Water is the child of metal, the child shelters in the mother’s womb" refers to black lead transforming in quality,
Taking its place in the west as the white tiger’s metal womb.
Water contains metal and again conceals its essence within the metal womb—
True mercury is such.
"The perfected one is most subtle, each guarding their own domain" means true mercury,
Driven by the external talismanic fire within the mother’s womb,
Now sinks, now rises,
Flying and hiding without constancy,
Now present, now absent.
Yet with the response of talismans and the advance and retreat of fire,
Each guards its own boundary,
Daring not to transgress.
Master Wei was enlightened by this chapter,
Profoundly clarifying the inner images of perception,
Yet still unable to match the state of true essence’s subtle and imperceptible arising and vanishing.
How wondrous! How divine!

**Chapter Twenty-Five: The White of Gathering**

Gathering the white of its kind,
Refining it yields the vermilion.
Tempered as defense and guard,
White enfolds the steadfast core.
Square and round, a inch in span,
Blended yet mutually bound.
Born before heaven and earth,
Majestic and supremely exalted.

"Gathering the white of its kind" means that at the first stirring of movement, white metal takes precedence.
"Refining it yields the vermilion" means that in the forging, next the blazing fire completes the crimson.
"Tempered as defense and guard, white enfolds the steadfast core" describes how white metal serves as the divine chamber.
"Square and round, a inch in span, blended yet mutually bound" means the metal womb resembles the primordial chaos in form. It is crafted by dividing the upper and lower crescents, with the central chamber square and round, an inch in diameter, to house the true mercury. Once the two children unite, the seal is firm and impervious, allowing yin and yang to correspond without the slightest leak, nurturing the dragon and tiger. As the *Ancient Song* says: "When the womb’s seal is unbroken, transformation occurs in an instant."

"Born before heaven and earth, majestic and supremely exalted" means that true lead existed before the primordial chaos of heaven and earth. Lead attained unity and took form, then gradually gave rise to heaven and earth, yin and yang, the five phases, the myriad things, and all beings. Thus, lead is the parent of heaven and earth, the root and origin of yin and yang. The sage delves into the root of heaven and earth’s parents to establish the foundation of the great elixir, gathering the pure essence of yin and yang to form the substance of the returned cinnabar. This is no ordinary creation of things.

Therefore, at the outset of elixir refinement, one must take the root of heaven and earth as the root of the medicine, and the mother of yin and yang as the mother of the cinnabar. If one cannot grasp the arising of heaven and earth and yin and yang in this interval, it is not the way of the golden liquid and returned cinnabar. If one uses what is produced *after* the existence of heaven and earth and yin and yang—such as the five metals, eight minerals, plant juices, wood ash, morning frost, night dew, snow broth, ice water, green salt, white brine, or any miscellaneous substances—how could success be anything but difficult?

Let those of like mind ponder this deeply, and in time, they will awaken. Thus, a later passage says: "After ten thousand repetitions, it may be grasped in darkness; the divine and enlightened may then fashion a person." This is also found in the eighty-third chapter of the lower volume.

**Chapter Twenty-Six: The Adjoining Walls and Gates**

**Chapter Twenty-Six: The Adjoining Walls and Gates**

Walls stand beside the gates, resembling Penglai’s isles.
Encircled and sealed, the four paths wind and turn.
Guarded and secured, they bar all wickedness.
Curved chambers connect, warding against the unforeseen.
Here, primordial reflection thrives—
yet sorrow and toil find no place.
The chamber brims with spirit and qi,
none can detain it.
Those who preserve it flourish;
those who lose it perish.
In movement and stillness, rest and repose,
it ever abides with the practitioner.

When refining the Returned Cinnabar,
there are the altar, furnace, and cauldron,
upper and lower conjoined,
shaped like Penglai’s isles, open on all sides.
Within the cauldron lies the divine chamber, the golden embryo,
winding and linked;
without, the pivot and bolts secure it,
sealing all gaps to prevent the true qi from escaping.
Only then are stray thoughts stilled,
and primordial toil dispelled.
Though the defenses are firm,
and the chamber fills with spirit and qi,
one must still regulate and harmonize yin and yang,
exchanging and applying effort,
to retain and bind the true essence,
thus accomplishing transformation.
If the fire-tally is misapplied,
even with true essence within,
it will scatter and flee.
All depends on tempering water and fire,
preserving without loss—
then prosperity follows.
Thus, the true qi’s movement and stillness,
rest and repose,
ever abide with the practitioner.

**Chapter Twenty-Seven: The Methods of Testing and Concealment**

The methods of testing and concealment—
inward vision gives rise to thought.
Treading the steps of the Dipper’s lodges,
the six jia follow the days and hours.
The yin path suppresses nine and one,
confusing and disrupting the primordial womb.
Ingesting qi, the intestines rumble;
exhaling the upright, inhaling external evil.
Day and night, no outward sleep,
from dark moon to new, never ceasing.
The body grows daily weary,
distracted, as if deranged.
The hundred vessels seethe and race,
unable to settle in clarity.
Piling earth to raise altars,
morning and evening, reverent offerings.
Ghostly forms appear,
dreams stir with sighs.
The heart rejoices, the mind delights,
self-assured of long life.
Yet suddenly, death cuts short the years,
the corpse decays, the bones exposed.
Every act goes awry,
perverse and contrary, the pivot lost.
Such methods are many,
a thousand strands, ten thousand more.
Advancing and retreating, they defy the Yellow and the Old,
twisting and turning, they rebel against the Nine Capitals.

These are not the true methods of the Hidden Treasury—those #37 twisted paths that rebel against the Nine Capitals. Master Wei observes that世人 do not grasp the fundamental origin of the Great Dao/Way, instead rushing toward the crooked byways of side doors. Thus, some inwardly contemplate petty tricks, treading the steps of the demonic net, manipulating the Six Jia days and celestial stems—mere introductory steps for the ignorant. Others, when facing circumstances, #38 engage in qi-absorption, bedroom defenses, bending and stretching, grasping and sealing, holding breath and swallowing saliva. Through these, qi becomes chaotic, spirit exhausted, hun-souls wounded, po-souls wearied, leading the yang spirit to flee its palace, while yin thieves plunder the lungs and liver. This arises from internal and external mutual encroachment, the clash of yin and yang hours, the seven po wandering like dead corpses, the Three Corpses battling in the eyes, the hundred vessels seething, the Three Fields in turmoil. What was meant to ensure longevity instead harms life—how can one attain clarity and stillness?

Others externally erect altars and carve jade, sacrificing to wanton ghosts, hoping to encounter the Dao/Way and beg for extended years. This causes ghostly qi to infect essence and spirit, evil winds to rise in the heart’s chamber, sometimes manifesting in dreams, sometimes in apparitions of form and sound. They believe longevity is within reach, unaware that their fate lies in their own hands—only to hasten their demise, abandoning decayed remains. Such practices are manifold, all classified as heterodox paths.

Seeking to move yet remaining stuck, desiring speed yet slowing further, they rebel against the utmost truth, deviate from heavenly principle, falsely claim the title of "high Dao," openly defy the writings of the Yellow Emperor, obscure the true teachings, and entirely lose the essence of the Old Master’s intent. Therefore, Master Wei does not wish people to practice side doors. He urges them to #39 directly enter the true Dao/Way. Even if the various Hidden Treasury methods yield minor achievements, they ultimately cannot escape death and decay. Only the Golden Elixir of Returning Mercury, after ingestion, reverses aging into infancy, attaining the rank of True Person, sharing the eternal longevity of heaven’s position. Thus, the following text states:

Golden sand enters the five viscera,
mist scatters like wind and rain.
Steaming and permeating the four limbs,
complexion becomes joyful, lustrous, and fine.
White hair turns black,
new teeth regrow.
The old man reverts to youthful vigor,
the aged woman becomes a maiden.
Transforming form to escape worldly calamities,
they are called True Persons.

As stated in Chapter Thirty-Two of this scroll. The *Scripture of the Yellow Court* also says: "One hundred and twenty years may still be restored, but beyond this, cultivating the Dao/Way becomes truly difficult. One must await the Ninefold Transmutation and Eightfold Jade Elixir, where the radiance of sun and moon rescues the old and frail." Thus, it is clear that this method is the supreme path of ascending to heaven in broad daylight and achieving immortality.

**Chapter Twenty-Eight: The Enlightened Examine These Principles**
The enlightened examine these principles,
suddenly understanding their origin.
Diligently practicing them,
day and night without rest.
After three years of ingesting the elixir,
they lightly ascend and travel afar.
Crossing fire without burning,
entering water without getting wet.
Able to appear and disappear at will,
eternally joyful, free from sorrow.
When the Dao/Way is accomplished and virtue/power perfected,
they conceal themselves, awaiting the time.
The Great One #40 then summons them to dwell in the Central Continent #41.
When merits are fulfilled and ascension achieved,
they receive the register and chart.
Master Wei warns those who love the Dao/Way: examine and fathom these principles, and you will naturally attain clarity. Once obtained, practice diligently day and night, never slackening from beginning to end. After the elixir is completed and ingested for three years, you will lightly ascend and travel afar, unobstructed by water or fire, able to sit and vanish #42 or stand and appear. Secretly performing hidden virtues, concealing yourself to await the time, the Great One will summon you to relocate to the Central Continent. Counting the days, you will ascend, receive the register and chart.

The Great One is the overseer of elixir refinement. The Central Continent is the Divine Continent. When世人 first attain the Dao/Way, their names are engraved on golden tablets in this land #43, receiving the register and chart #44 to achieve ascension.

**Chapter Twenty-Nine: The Fire Record Is Not Falsely Composed**
The *Fire Record* is not falsely composed;
it elucidates the *Book of Changes* to clarify it.
The crescent-moon method of the crucible,
with the White Tiger as the pivot of refinement.
Mercury as the flowing pearl of the sun,
accompanied by the Azure Dragon.
Raising the east to meet the west,
hun and po naturally bind each other.
The waxing moon corresponds to the number eight of Dui,
the waning moon to the number eight of Gen.
When the essences of both phases merge,
the body of Qian and Kun is formed.
Two eights make a pound,
the Dao/Way of the *Changes* stands upright, unshaken.
A pound has three hundred eighty-four zhu,
also corresponding to the number of hexagrams and lines.
Though the fire has its record,
it must be regulated by the Dao/Way of the *Changes*,
following the hexagrams and lines,
circulating through Pi and Tai.
The crucible is shaped like an inverted moon,
the metal tiger within serves as the mechanism of the medicine.
Cinnabar mercury and the Azure Dragon,
pursued by the Vermilion Bird of Bing and Ding,
follow the time to enter the golden womb together—
hence called "raising the east to meet the west."
Hun and po refer to the eastern dragon’s hun and the western tiger’s po.
The upper and lower phases combine to form #45 a pound’s weight,
divided into three hundred eighty-four zhu,
corresponding to the two eights of a month’s cycle.
Thus, the forms of Qian and Kun are complete,
matching the number of a celestial revolution.

**Chapter Thirty: Gold Enters the Fierce Fire**
Gold enters the fierce fire,
its color unaltered, its radiance undiminished.
Since the beginning of creation,
the sun and moon have never lost their brightness,
gold has never lost its weight,
the sun and moon retain their usual forms.
Gold is originally born from the moon,
receiving the sun’s tally at the new moon.
Gold returns to its mother,
as the moon wanes, the sun envelops it.
Concealing its frame,
it sinks into the cavernous void.
Gold regains its original nature,
its majestic light rejoicing in the crucible #46.
The five phases overcome each other,
fire overcomes metal.
Yet when metal encounters fire, it can be forged into tools,
neither harming the other.
Thus, the golden womb in the crucible does not dissipate,
its golden color growing ever more luminous.
Since the establishment of the Qian and Kun crucible,
the sun and moon’s essences enter within,
mutually benefiting each other,
both retaining their brightness.
The gold’s weight remains unchanged,
the sun and moon perpetually encircle and illuminate.
Gold is originally born from the moon—
gold is yin essence, residing in the west,
hence it is said that gold is born from the moon.
From the new moon, it receives the tally of the celestial stems,
thus generating gold.

When gold returns to its mother,
the moon receives its mandate in turn,
gold reverts to water.
When the moon wanes and yang qi is wholly spent,
then gold and water—these two substances—
naturally enfold each other in their nature,
concealing their frame and sinking into the cavernous void.
The waning moon mirrors the year’s end,
the new moon mirrors the year’s beginning.

When gold and water take form,
the crucible-chamber perpetually contains harmonious qi,
and thus success is manifest—
hence it is said the crucible rejoices #47.
Joy brings harmony,
harmony brings gold and water to congeal,
and the Dao of spontaneity is complete.

**The Union of Zi and Wu Numbers, Third Stanza, Thirty-First**
The zi and wu numbers unite as three,
while wu and ji are called five.
When three and five harmonize,
the eight minerals stand as the proper norm.
Inhalation and exhalation yearn for each other #48,
longing to become husband and wife.
Yellow earth is gold’s father,
flowing pearl is water’s mother #49.
Water takes earth as its ghost—
earth subdues water, preventing its rise.
The Vermilion Bird is the essence of fire,
holding balance to adjust victory and defeat.
When water prevails, fire is extinguished,
both perishing to return to the fertile earth.
Once the three natures unite,
their original nature shares a common ancestor.

The zi water is numbered one,
the wu fire is numbered two—
together they form three.
Wu-ji earth is numbered five,
and three and five combine to make eight—
thus, when three and five harmonize,
the eight minerals stand as the proper norm.
Hence the Azure Dragon exhales to the White Tiger,
the White Tiger inhales the dragon’s essence,
their breath mutually nourishing,
longing to become husband and wife.

Yellow earth is gold’s father,
flowing pearl is water’s mother—
earth restrains #50 cinnabar mercury,
preventing its dispersal,
as when the tail of fire governs earth in the four seasons.
Gold is wholly from the Vermilion Bird’s fire spirit,
which regulates victory and defeat.
When water prevails, fire is extinguished,
and both wane and new moon come to an end,
their merit returning to earth’s virtue.
When the three natures unite,
their original nature shares a common ancestor #51—
for gold and fire emerge from the single qi of water,
being born within the primordial nine qi before heaven and earth,
capable of generating the five phases,
not merely the two substances of gold and fire.

**The Sesame Extends Longevity, Thirty-Second Stanza**
Sesame extends longevity,
returned elixir may enter the mouth.
Gold’s nature does not decay,
thus it is the treasure of the ten thousand things.
When adepts ingest it,
their lifespan is prolonged.
Earth travels through the four seasons,
guarding its boundaries and setting its rules.
Golden sand enters the five viscera,
dispersing like mist or wind and rain.
Steaming and permeating the four limbs,
the complexion becomes joyful and lustrous.
White hair all turns black,
fallen teeth regrow in their original place.
Old men regain youthful vigor,
aged women become maidens.
Transforming their form, they escape worldly calamity—
sesame is called the True Person.

Sesame #52—
if mere mortals consume it and still gain longevity,
how much more so when the golden liquid returned elixir enters the mouth?
The elixir first arises from true gold—
true gold #53, the mother of things,
serves as the foundation of the medicine,
nourishing the viscera and limbs,
enabling long vision.

Is not long life assured?
Gold’s essence never decays.
It is the ancestor of heaven and earth’s primordial qi—
as the *Daodejing* says:
“The nameless is the beginning of heaven and earth,
the named is the mother of the ten thousand things.”
Before heaven and earth, a single qi was the origin,
giving birth to the ten thousand images.
Gold is the root of water,
and thus true gold, the mother, can produce golden sand and returned elixir.

Earth travels through the four seasons—
Master Wei uses this to instruct later generations in refining and ingesting the medicine.
When this sand enters the mouth,
it marks the beginning and end of the elixir path.
Its numinous wonders are beyond measure,
like clouds, mist, wind, and rain—
rejuvenating the old and reversing aging,
transforming the myriad paths to enter the five phases,
causing teeth to regrow and hair to darken,
thus achieving long life.

**Lead Powder Cast into Fire, Thirty-Third Stanza**
When lead powder is cast into fire,
its color is ruined and it reverts to lead.
When ice and snow meet warm broth,
they dissolve and become the Great Mystery.
Gold takes cinnabar as its master,
receiving harmony from mercury.
Transformation arises from its authenticity,
beginning and end naturally follow one another.
If you wish to become an immortal through ingestion,
you must use substances of the same kind.
Plant millet to grow millet,
hatch chickens with their own eggs #54.
Assisting nature with its own kind,
things are easily shaped and refined.
Can fish eyes be considered pearls?
Can thistles and thorns become fine boxes?
Only those of the same kind follow one another—
deviant methods do not produce treasures.

Thus, swallows and sparrows do not give birth to phoenixes,
foxes and hares do not nurse horses.
Water does not flow upward in flames,
fire does not moisten downward.

Lead white is refined from black lead; when cast into fire, it reverts to lead. Snow and frost form from water qi; when warmed by broth, they return to water. Gold sand and mercury are of one body—gold serves as the mother, giving birth to cinnabar and mercury. Thus it is said: plant millet to grow millet, hatch chickens with their own eggs. Once they receive sufficient qi, they become millet and chickens. This is the Dao of kind begetting kind, of beginning and end naturally following one another.

To use metals, minerals, herbs, frost, dew, ice, snow, salt, or brine would be a grievous error—this has been thoroughly explained in the annotations above. In the twenty-fifth chapter of this scroll, the root of Heaven and Earth is taken as the root of the elixir, and true gold mother as the mother of the elixir. Now it produces yin-yang essence, golden cinnabar, and numinous mercury as the medicine of immortality—is this not so?

Thus it is said: swallows and sparrows do not give birth to phoenixes, foxes and hares do not nurse horses. Fire’s nature is to flame upward—it cannot be made to moisten downward. Water’s nature is to moisten downward—it cannot be made to flame upward. Since this is the root of their natural natures, by analogy, the gold mother producing golden cinnabar is self-evident.

**The World Abounds with Scholars (Chapter Thirty-Four)**

The world abounds with scholars,
men of lofty skill and rare talent.
Yet by chance they meet no opportunity,
wasting fire and squandering wealth.
They cling to texts and follow words,
recklessly imposing their own ideas.
The thread of origin loses its reason,
measure and grasp slip from their hold.

Refining malachite and chalcanthite, mica and reputed magnetite,
sulphur burning in camphorwood, mud and mercury smelted in flight.
Bellows forge the five-stone bronze, using it as the pivot’s aid.
Yet their natures differ in kind—how could they dwell as one body?
A thousand attempts must fail ten thousand times; seeking transmutation, one becomes a fool.
Fortune never favors them—only the sage truly knows.
From youth to white-haired age, midway they breed doubt,
abandoning the Dao to cling to deluded paths, stepping from the straight into crooked byways.
Peering through a tube, their vision is not broad—how can they fathom what lies ahead?

Master Wei says: The world teems with broadly learned, erudite scholars who fix their minds on the realm of the Dao, fond of fiery pursuit of the Mystery. By chance, they fail to meet an enlightened teacher, relying only on texts and secret formulas, recklessly imposing their own ideas. They waste their wealth, refining miscellaneous medicines, hoping for transcendence and eternal life. Through the years to hoary age, they persist without turning back, stubbornly clinging to their narrow view, straying into false paths. A thousand attempts, ten thousand failures—how can they gauge the future? Their natures differ in kind; this was already explained in the annotation above.

**Of the Utmost Sages (Chapter Thirty-Five)**

Of the utmost sages, none surpass Fuxi,
who first drew the Eight Trigrams, modeling Heaven and Earth.
King Wen, imperial ancestor, structured the hexagrams and composed their judgments.
Confucius, the near-sage hero, supplemented them with the *Ten Wings*.
These three lords were Heaven’s chosen, rising in succession to govern their times.
Though their ranks differ in steps, their merits and virtues do not diverge.
Their creations followed precedent, weighing and measuring with meticulous care.
What has form is easily reckoned; what lacks omen is hard to plan.
Their deeds became models for all, their works established the *Odes* and *Documents*.
Devoid of prior knowledge, they awakened through their teachers.
Bright as if parting the curtains, they opened their eyes to ascend the high terrace.

Master Wei extols Fuxi, King Wen, and Confucius—the three sages Heaven-endowed with divine intelligence, each possessing luminous virtue. In expounding the *Dao* of the *Yijing*, they penetrated the essence of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things. In editing the *Odes* and *Documents*, they distilled the teachings of rulers, ministers, and the multitudes. They further established hexagram images, analyzed weights and measures, and calculated the cycles of celestial bodies, exhausting the numbers of the *Great Expansion*.
Though Heaven and Earth are vast, they cannot seal the mechanisms of closure and openness.
Though yin and yang are utterly void, they conceal the reckoning of movement and stillness.
Thus the sages drew upon them to devise the great Dao, using qian and kun to symbolize the cauldron and chamber, causing them to embrace the One qi and govern the ten thousand spirits, threading yin and yang through the hours, enabling the six voids to generate all beings.
What has form is easily reckoned—Heaven and Earth.
What lacks omen is hard to plan—yin and yang.
Without the three sages’ exposition of the *Yijing*, by what path would water and fire be deployed?
Without the legacy of their writings for ten thousand generations, by what gate would dragon and tiger be harnessed?
Thus it is said: Devoid of prior knowledge, they awakened through this.
As if parting the curtains, clarity dawned.
As if ascending the high terrace, nothing remained beyond their ken.
This metaphor illustrates the sages’ Dao: the higher one looks, the loftier it becomes; the deeper one delves, the more impenetrable it grows.
Through the *Dao* of the *Yijing*, the *Fire Records* are further illuminated—this will be briefly explained below.

**The Fire Records’ Six Hundred Chapters (Chapter Thirty-Six)**

The *Fire Records* comprise six hundred chapters, their aims not differing in essence.
Their texts expound with solemn care, yet the world does not ponder deeply.
Tracing their source and flow, the hidden and manifest originally dwell as one.
I speak in confidence to the worthy—how dare I treat this lightly in writing?
If I were to seal my tongue and wither, cutting off the Dao, I would incur guilt and punishment.
Yet to express my thoughts on bamboo and silk, I fear revealing Heaven’s tally.
Hesitant, I sigh in lament, gazing up and down, appending this folly.
Refinement and cooling follow method and measure—I cannot bear to lay them all bare.
I shall briefly outline their guiding principles; their branches and twigs will be seen in due course.

**Six Hundred Chapters (Continued)**

The *Fire Records*’ six hundred chapters represent the grand reckoning of fire’s cyclical movement under the stars, each dawn and dusk governed by a hexagram’s charge. Though termed six hundred chapters, their sequence remains uniform—thus the year aligns with the month, the month with the day, the day with the hour. Master Wei dared neither seal his tongue to obscure the great Dao nor commit it openly to bamboo and silk, lest he reveal Heaven’s mechanism. Hesitant and sighing, he feared his words might fail posterity. Thus, he briefly sketched their guiding principles, hinting at their branches, while reserving finer details for oral transmission.

---

**Chapter Thirty-Seven: Using Metal as a Dike**

Use metal as a dike, and water enters in leisurely flow.
Metal’s reckoning is fifteen; water’s count matches it.
Before the furnace, fix the weights—water exceeds by five parts.
When these two are deemed true, metal’s weight returns to its origin.
The third does not enter; fire and the other two accompany it.
The three substances unite, their transformations wondrous as spirits.
Beneath lies the qi of Grand Yang, steaming in but a moment.
First it liquefies, then congeals—this is called the Yellow Chariot.
As years and months near their end, nature is undone, lifespan harmed.
The body becomes ash and dust, its form like dust on a bright window.

The Metal Mother resides in the central palace, serving as a dike for quicksilver. Thus, metal and water flow in harmony, their natures entwined. Metal and water follow the celestial stems, each receiving half the qi, together making a full catty’s measure. Having produced golden cinnabar, the mother remains undiminished—hence it is said, “metal’s weight returns to its origin.” The third that does not enter is true earth. Metal, fire, and wood—these three substances, driven by water and fire through the celestial stems, enter the vessel together. There, the three natures converge, the two flavors bind, and their transformations become wondrous as spirits.

The Metal Mother, steamed by the essence and qi of Grand Yang, first exudes liquid, then solidifies—this is named the Yellow Chariot. Through the cycles of stars, yin and yang, and the Five Phases, their functions are tested and interwoven. Retreating to conceal their forms, all merit returns to the central palace. The Yellow Emperor embodies the power of earth—thus it is said, “nature is undone, lifespan harmed.” Returning to earth’s power, they transform into earth, their spirit and essence resembling dust on a bright window.

---

**Chapter Thirty-Eight: Pounding, Refining, and Combining**

Pound and refine them together, then hold them to enter the Crimson Gate.
Seal their junctures firmly, ensuring perfection and strength.
Blazing fire rises from below, its roar ceaseless day and night.
Begin with civil fire, refine it; end with martial fire, array it.
Observe with utmost care, scrutinizing the balance of cold and warmth.
Cycle through the twelve nodes; when each ends, renew your vigilance.
When qi wanes and life nears its end, rest to revive the hun and po.
The color shifts to purple, resplendent—returned cinnabar is formed.
Knead it into a single pellet; the spatula’s touch is most divine.

Pound and refine the elixir’s foundation, fortifying and sealing it, then place it within the crucible—this is called the Crimson Gate. Water flows downward, fire blazes upward; waxing and waning advance and retreat, ascending and descending by day and night. Civil fire begins at midnight, martial fire follows until noon. From noon, the yin tally arises, continuing to midnight. Their movements alternate between closure and opening, regulated by cold and warmth. When the twelve nodes conclude, the cycle renews. Once the fire’s course is complete, the hun and po transform their forms. Turning to purple gold, resplendent cinnabar is achieved. Ingesting a single grain, the spatula’s touch becomes divine. The marvel of this work defies full description.

---

**Chapter Thirty-Nine: Calculating the Numbers of the Five Phases**

Calculate the numbers of the Five Phases—they are concise, not cumbersome.
Raise water to strike fire, and its light is suddenly extinguished.
Sun and moon press close, ever between waxing and waning.
When water prevails, Kan encroaches on yang; when fire weakens, Li’s day darkens.
Yin and yang consume each other, their intercourse the Dao’s natural course.

The Five Phases are the qi of emptiness and nothingness, elusive and hard to name. If measured by the total reckoning of Heaven and Earth, their workings elude capture, yet within the crucible, the Five Phases bind themselves. Yin and yang mate, fire rises as water recedes, water excites fire’s decline. The sun’s essence stirs at dawn’s waning, the moon’s po concludes at dusk’s end. Male and female alternate, cinnabar and mercury engender one another. By Heaven and Earth’s nature, the Dao of the elixir is revealed.

---

**Chapter Forty: Names Define Essence**

Names define essence; graphs express the nature of words.
When metal returns to its original nature, it is called Returned Cinnabar.
I dare not speak falsely, emulating the sages’ texts.
Ancient records praise Dragon and Tiger; the Yellow Emperor extolled Golden Flower.
Huainan refined Autumn Stone; Wang Yang added Yellow Sprout.
The worthy may uphold and practice this; the unworthy must not partake.
The Dao of past and present remains one—face-to-face, we speak of what is planned.
Scholars, redouble your efforts, lingering in deep reflection.
The essential words are plainly revealed, shining bright—they do not deceive me.

Metal is essence; water is nature. Since metal gives birth to quicksilver, essence returns to nature. Moreover, metal is born of water, making water the mother of metal. Water, in turn, is born of metal, so metal becomes the mother of water—hence the name Returned Cinnabar. As stated earlier, “the mother conceals the child’s embryo, the child shelters the mother’s womb.” In the twenty-fourth chapter of this scroll, it is said...

Yet the Master Wei’s confusion bequeathed a legacy of emptiness and deceit, as he invoked the imagery of the *Book of Changes* and the *Ancient Dragon-Tiger Classic* to expound his teachings, further extolling the Yellow Emperor, Huainan, Wang Yang, and the Perfected Sages—all of whom could uphold and practice this Way. The path of past and present shares a single gateway, unattainable to the unworthy.
